title: Detailed writeup on LAPSUS$ Cybercriminal Group who have compromised Microsoft and Okta

meta.title: Detailed writeup on LAPSUS$ Cybercriminal Group who have compromised Microsoft and Okta

sentences.text: by
anirudh.batra
Source: A1<crlf>Industry: IT & Technology<crlf>Region: USA<crlf>Category: Adversary Intelligence

chapters.title: Detailed writeup on LAPSUS$ Cybercriminal Group who have compromised Microsoft and Okta

sentences.text: CloudSEKs flagship digital risk monitoring platform XVigil discovered a post on Telegram, sharing the Nvidia employee credentials, Samsungs Source code along with that the latest addition to those already high profile targets are Microsofts Cortana and Bings Source code and Okta the SSO giants customer data was exfiltrated.<crlf>Lapsus$ ransomware gang claimed to have compromised Nvidia and now targets Samsung with the breach. Further claiming to have gained access to source code used in Samsung Galaxy smartphones, Oktas Customer data etc.
sentences.html:
• CloudSEK’s flagship digital risk monitoring platform XVigil discovered a post on Telegram, sharing the Nvidia employee credentials, Samsung’s Source code along with that the latest addition to those already high profile targets are Microsoft’s Cortana and Bing’s Source code and Okta the SSO giant’s customer data was exfiltrated.
  • Lapsus$ ransomware gang claimed to have compromised Nvidia and now targets Samsung with the breach. Further claiming to have gained access to source code used in Samsung Galaxy smartphones, Okta’s Customer data etc.

sentences.text: The ransomware gang leaked source code, dehashed credentials, code signing certificates and source code to the driver. The leaked data unlocks the potential for threat actors to gain unauthorized access to personal, proprietary, and Intellectual Property (IP) data of Nvidia and they have also leaked 90% source code of Bing Maps, Bing and Cortana claiming to be at 45%.<crlf>While writing this report, we have discovered that PII (Personally Identifiable Information) or dox Information related to the Lapsus$ ransomware gang was released at a Russian language cybercrime forum.
sentences.html:
• The ransomware gang leaked source code, dehashed credentials, code signing certificates and source code to the driver. The leaked data unlocks the potential for threat actors to gain unauthorized access to personal, proprietary, and Intellectual Property (IP) data of Nvidia and they have also leaked 90% source code of Bing Maps, Bing and Cortana claiming to be at 45%.
  • While writing this report, we have discovered that PII (Personally Identifiable Information) or dox Information related to the Lapsus$ ransomware gang was released at a Russian language cybercrime forum.

sentences.text: This screenshot was posted on the telegram group and while analyzing closely we can see that they have access to Jira, Slack, G-Suite and other internal applications as well. RDP access is being used in the screenshot

On 22nd March, 2022 the group claimed to leak Bing Maps, Bing and Cortana source code. Our threat Intelligence team has confirmed that these claims are true, shortly after there were official blogs from Microsoft and Okta confirming the breach.
sentences.html: On 22nd March, 2022 the group claimed to leak Bing Maps, Bing and Cortana source code. Our threat Intelligence team has confirmed that these claims are true, shortly after there were official blogs from Microsoft and Okta confirming the breach.

sentences.text: Leaked Information shared on Telegram Channels
The LAPSUS$ cyber-criminal group has been known to exploit the weakest link in the security chain of a corporate network: Human mistakes and bad practices.
sentences.html: The LAPSUS$ cyber-criminal group has been known to exploit the weakest link in the security chain of a corporate network: Human mistakes and bad practices.

sentences.text: They achieve initial access using the following tactics:
sentences.html: They achieve initial access using the following tactics:

sentences.text: Redline Malware stealer logs, which can be understood here<crlf>Popular market places like amigos, russian-market to get logs, credentials and session tokens to get access.<crlf>They are known to pay insiders to provide them with VPN, VDI(citrix), Identity providers and even RDP access
sentences.html:
• Redline Malware stealer logs, which can be understood here
  • Popular market places like amigos, russian-market to get logs, credentials and session tokens to get access.
  • They are known to pay insiders to provide them with VPN, VDI(citrix), Identity providers and even RDP access

sentences.text: Lapsus Recruitment Post
Publicly available secrets on github/gitlab repositories
The next steps involve Privilege escalation and Post Exploitation:
sentences.html: The next steps involve Privilege escalation and Post Exploitation:

sentences.text: Exploiting existing vulnerabilities which include unpatched versions of Jira, confluence, Fortiguard, Microsoft exchange servers etc.. We have created a list of curated vulnerabilities that they target<crlf>Accessing version control systems and looking at private repositories to gain access to secrets and gems<crlf>They also access mailboxes/collaboration software like slack to get access to credentials being shared in plain text.
sentences.html:
• Exploiting existing vulnerabilities which include unpatched versions of Jira, confluence, Fortiguard, Microsoft exchange servers etc.. We have created a list of curated vulnerabilities that they target
  • Accessing version control systems and looking at private repositories to gain access to secrets and gems
  • They also access mailboxes/collaboration software like slack to get access to credentials being shared in plain text.

sentences.text: They have highlighted the post-exploitation steps they took as a part of the response to Oktas latest blog.
Microsoft in an official blog today has stated the following:
sentences.html: Microsoft in an official blog today has stated the following:

sentences.text: This week, the actor made public claims that they had gained access to Microsoft and exfiltrated portions of source code. No customer code or data was involved in the observed activities. Our investigation has found a single account had been compromised, granting limited access. Our cybersecurity response teams quickly engaged to remediate the compromised account and prevent further activity. Microsoft does not rely on the secrecy of code as a security measure and viewing source code does not lead to elevation of risk.
sentences.html: “This week, the actor made public claims that they had gained access to Microsoft and exfiltrated portions of source code. No customer code or data was involved in the observed activities. Our investigation has found a single account had been compromised, granting limited access. Our cybersecurity response teams quickly engaged to remediate the compromised account and prevent further activity. Microsoft does not rely on the secrecy of code as a security measure and viewing source code does not lead to elevation of risk.”

sentences.text: The leak contains 56484 directories, 333743 files and the source code for Cortana, Bing Maps and Bing. The aggregate size of the data leaked is 37.8 GB.
sentences.html: The leak contains 56484 directories, 333743 files and the source code for Cortana, Bing Maps and Bing. The aggregate size of the data leaked is 37.8 GB.

sentences.text: The leak also contains multiple sensitive endpoints like the one mentioned in the above screenshot. Similarly there are 135 .pfx files which are present in the leak. A pfx file contains the SSL certificate(public key) and the corresponding private key. These can in turn be used maliciously.
sentences.html: The leak also contains multiple sensitive endpoints like the one mentioned in the above screenshot. Similarly there are 135 .pfx files which are present in the leak. A pfx file contains the SSL certificate(public key) and the corresponding private key. These can in turn be used maliciously.

sentences.text: There are documentation files as well as internal pdf files:
sentences.html: There are documentation files as well as internal pdf files:

sentences.text: By looking at the files we can conclude the following:
sentences.html: By looking at the files we can conclude the following:

sentences.text: No customer data was affected<crlf>No PII was leaked<crlf>Source code along with certificates and pfx files were leaked<crlf>The Lapsus$ group is not very strong with Operational Security as they posted a Proof of Concept in the Telegram channel while the exfiltration was still underway
sentences.html:
• No customer data was affected
  • No PII was leaked
  • Source code along with certificates and pfx files were leaked
  • The Lapsus$ group is not very strong with Operational Security as they posted a Proof of Concept in the Telegram channel while the exfiltration was still underway

sentences.text: Okta has also released a statement earlier in the form of a blog stating:
sentences.html: Okta has also released a statement earlier in the form of a blog stating:

sentences.text: Okta detected an unsuccessful attempt to compromise the account of a customer support engineer working for a third-party provider. As part of our regular procedures, we alerted the provider to the situation, while simultaneously terminating the users active Okta sessions and suspending the individuals account. Following those actions, we shared pertinent information (including suspicious IP addresses) to supplement their investigation, which was supported by a third-party forensics firm.
sentences.html: “Okta detected an unsuccessful attempt to compromise the account of a customer support engineer working for a third-party provider. As part of our regular procedures, we alerted the provider to the situation, while simultaneously terminating the user’s active Okta sessions and suspending the individual’s account. Following those actions, we shared pertinent information (including suspicious IP addresses) to supplement their investigation, which was supported by a third-party forensics firm.”

sentences.text: After a thorough analysis of these claims, we have concluded that a small percentage of customers approximately 2.5% have potentially been impacted and whose data may have been viewed or acted upon. We have identified those customers and are contacting them directly. If you are an Okta customer and were impacted, we have already reached out directly by email. We are sharing this interim update, consistent with our values of customer success, integrity, and transparency
sentences.html: “After a thorough analysis of these claims, we have concluded that a small percentage of customers – approximately 2.5% – have potentially been impacted and whose data may have been viewed or acted upon. We have identified those customers and are contacting them directly. If you are an Okta customer and were impacted, we have already reached out directly by email. We are sharing this interim update, consistent with our values of customer success, integrity, and transparency”

sentences.text: In response to the above statement, Lapsus$ group has also released a message which can be summarized in the following points:
sentences.html: In response to the above statement, Lapsus$ group has also released a message which can be summarized in the following points:

sentences.text: They were successful in breaching a Superuser/Admin account that had access to Slack, Jira, Confluence boards etc ..<crlf>It is suspicious that the customer support engineer had access to ~8.6k slack channels and internal applications.<crlf>They had access to internal AWS secret and key pairs/ other API keys as they were being shared in plain text over Slack and emails<crlf>The breached account had the ability to reset the Password and MFA of ~95% of their clientele
sentences.html:
• They were successful in breaching a Superuser/Admin account that had access to Slack, Jira, Confluence boards etc ..
  • It is suspicious that the customer support engineer had access to ~8.6k slack channels and internal applications.
  • They had access to internal AWS secret and key pairs/ other API keys as they were being shared in plain text over Slack and emails
  • The breached account had the ability to reset the Password and MFA of ~95% of their clientele

sentences.text: The screenshot was shared by Lapsus as a POC claiming they had access to Slack and other applications.

chapters.title: Information from the Cyber Crime forum

sentences.text: Lapsus Ransomware group emerged in early January 2022.
sentences.html: Lapsus Ransomware group emerged in early January 2022.

sentences.text: The group is actively operating over their Telegram channel and engages with subscribers. They keep their subscribers updated on their upcoming data breaches and host polls.<crlf>Recently, we came across a post on a Russian speaking cybercrime forum that mentioned PII as the operator of the Lapsus$ group.
sentences.html:
• The group is actively operating over their Telegram channel and engages with subscribers. They keep their subscribers updated on their upcoming data breaches and host polls.
  • Recently, we came across a post on a Russian speaking cybercrime forum that mentioned PII as the operator of the Lapsus$ group.

sentences.text: The doxed information shows a lot of personal information: Name: Arion Kurtaj Interests: Minecraft, Fishing, selling 0days Age: 16 years Potential Address: Spain Nationality: British DOB: February 19th, 2005 Personal Emails:<crlf>Name: Arion Kurtaj<crlf>Interests: Minecraft, Fishing, selling 0days<crlf>Age: 16 years<crlf>Potential Address: Spain<crlf>Nationality: British<crlf>DOB: February 19th, 2005<crlf>Personal Emails:
sentences.html:
• The doxed information shows a lot of personal information:
    • Name: Arion Kurtaj
    • Interests: Minecraft, Fishing, selling 0days
    • Age: 16 years
    • Potential Address: Spain
    • Nationality: British
    • DOB: February 19th, 2005
    • Personal Emails:

sentences.text: Aliases:
Lapsus$ gang previously targeted an organization in Nepal and an investigation blog was published for the same mentioning the targeted CVEs.
sentences.html: Lapsus$ gang previously targeted an organization in Nepal and an investigation blog was published for the same mentioning the targeted CVEs.

0.2: CVE-2022-0139: Use After Free in GitHub repository radareorg/radare2 prior to 5.6.0
0.3: CVE-2021-45327: Trusting HTTP Permission Methods on the Server Side when referencing the vulnerable admin or user API
0.4: CVE-2021-45325: SSRF vulneraility exists in Gitea before 1.7.0 using the OpenID URL
0.5: CVE-2021-44956: Two Heap based buffer overflow vulnerabilities exist in ffjpeg through 01.01.2021
0.6: CVE-2021-34473: Microsoft Exchange Server Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
0.7: CVE-2021-26858: Microsoft Exchange Server Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
0.8: CVE-2021-26855: Microsoft Exchange Server Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
0.9: CVE-2020-23705: A global buffer overflow vulnerability through 2020-06-22
0.10: CVE-2019-5591: A Default Configuration vulnerability in FortiOS

1.1: CVE-2022-0510: XSS reflected in Packagist pimcore/pimcore prior to 10.3.1.
1.2: CVE-2021-45328: URL Redirection to Untrusted Site (‘Open Redirect’) via internal URLs
1.3: CVE-2021-45326: CSRF vulnerability exists in Gitea before 1.5.2 via API routes
1.4: CVE-2021-44957: Global buffer overflow vulnerability exist in ffjpeg through 01.01.2021
1.5: CVE-2021-44864: TP-Link WR886N 3.0 1.0.1 Build 150127 Rel.34123n is vulnerable to Buffer Overflow
1.6: CVE-2021-31207: Microsoft Exchange Server Security Feature Bypass Vulnerability
1.7: CVE-2021-26857: Microsoft Exchange Server Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
1.8: CVE-2020-23852: A heap based buffer overflow vulnerability exists in ffjpeg through 2020-07-02
1.9: CVE-2020-12812: An improper authentication vulnerability in SSL VPN in FortiOS
1.10: CVE-2018-13379: An Improper Limitation of a Pathname to a Restricted Directory (“Path Traversal”) in Fortinet

sentences.text: CVEs targeted by Lapsus$<crlf>CVE-2022-21702: XSS vulnerability in Grafana<crlf>CVE-2022-0510: XSS reflected in Packagist pimcore/pimcore prior to 10.3.1.<crlf>CVE-2022-0139: Use After Free in GitHub repository radareorg/radare2 prior to 5.6.0<crlf>CVE-2021-45328: URL Redirection to Untrusted Site (Open Redirect) via internal URLs<crlf>CVE-2021-45327: Trusting HTTP Permission Methods on the Server Side when referencing the vulnerable admin or user API<crlf>CVE-2021-45326: CSRF vulnerability exists in Gitea before 1.5.2 via API routes<crlf>CVE-2021-45325: SSRF vulneraility exists in Gitea before 1.7.0 using the OpenID URL<crlf>CVE-2021-44957: Global buffer overflow vulnerability exist in ffjpeg through 01.01.2021<crlf>CVE-2021-44956: Two Heap based buffer overflow vulnerabilities exist in ffjpeg through 01.01.2021<crlf>CVE-2021-44864: TP-Link WR886N 3.0 1.0.1 Build 150127 Rel.34123n is vulnerable to Buffer Overflow<crlf>CVE-2021-34473: Microsoft Exchange Server Remote Code Execution Vulnerability<crlf>CVE-2021-31207: Microsoft Exchange Server Security Feature Bypass Vulnerability<crlf>CVE-2021-26858: Microsoft Exchange Server Remote Code Execution Vulnerability<crlf>CVE-2021-26857: Microsoft Exchange Server Remote Code Execution Vulnerability<crlf>CVE-2021-26855: Microsoft Exchange Server Remote Code Execution Vulnerability<crlf>CVE-2020-23852: A heap based buffer overflow vulnerability exists in ffjpeg through 2020-07-02<crlf>CVE-2020-23705: A global buffer overflow vulnerability through 2020-06-22<crlf>CVE-2020-12812: An improper authentication vulnerability in SSL VPN in FortiOS<crlf>CVE-2019-5591: A Default Configuration vulnerability in FortiOS<crlf>CVE-2018-13379: An Improper Limitation of a Pathname to a Restricted Directory (Path Traversal) in Fortinet

Nvidia was targeted by Lapsus$ group last month. Subsequently, earlier this month, malware samples began to appear in the wild, signed with Nvidia certificates. Some of these samples have got very low detection on VirusTotal because of the legitimate certificates attached, and hence could pose a threat. Following are the malware samples signed with stolen certificates:
sentences.html: Nvidia was targeted by Lapsus$ group last month. Subsequently, earlier this month, malware samples began to appear in the wild, signed with Nvidia certificates. Some of these samples have got very low detection on VirusTotal because of the legitimate certificates attached, and hence could pose a threat. Following are the malware samples signed with stolen certificates:

0.1: The published credentials could enable other threat actors to gain access to the organization’s networks. The exposed Personally Identifiable Information (PII) could enable threat actors to orchestrate social engineering schemes, phishing attacks, and even identity theft. Since password reuse is a common practice, threat actors could leverage the exposed credentials to gain access to the users’ other accounts. Exposed IP addresses and login credentials can lead to potential account takeovers.The exposed confidential details could reveal business practices and intellectual property.

1.1: Reset the compromised user login credentials and Implement a strong password policy for all user accounts. Check for possible workarounds and patches while keeping the ports open. Use MFA (multi-factor authentication) across logins.Patch all vulnerable and exploitable endpoints. Monitor for anomalies, in user accounts and systems, that could be indicators of possible takeovers.

sentences.text: Impact<crlf>Mitigation<crlf>The published credentials could enable other threat actors to gain access to the organizations networks. The exposed Personally Identifiable Information (PII) could enable threat actors to orchestrate social engineering schemes, phishing attacks, and even identity theft. Since password reuse is a common practice, threat actors could leverage the exposed credentials to gain access to the users other accounts. Exposed IP addresses and login credentials can lead to potential account takeovers.The exposed confidential details could reveal business practices and intellectual property.<crlf>Reset the compromised user login credentials and Implement a strong password policy for all user accounts. Check for possible workarounds and patches while keeping the ports open. Use MFA (multi-factor authentication) across logins.Patch all vulnerable and exploitable endpoints. Monitor for anomalies, in user accounts and systems, that could be indicators of possible takeovers.
